Purpose
To ensure that sonographers are aware of what procedures to follow when assessing fetal growth.
To ensure that ultrasound staff are aware of the optimum timing of scans.
To ensure that midwives and doctors are aware of referral criteria for the assessment of fetal growth.
Scope
This document encompasses all women who consent for an ultrasound scan for the assessment of fetal growth.
Indications for a Growth Scan
For the GROW programme, requests should be made directly with the ultrasound department and appointments should be made as soon as possible within 4 days.
GROW programme
(Refer to guideline entitled ‘Assessment of fetal growth during the antenatal period' no. 15004)
First fundal height measures below the th centile at 26-28 weeks gestation;
Static growth: no increase in sequential measurements;
Slow growth: curve linking up plots crossing centiles in the downward direction;
Excessive growth: curve linking up plots crossing centiles in an upward direction;
If the following measurements remain above the th centile but follows the curve this is normal growth and a referral for a scan is not required.

Serial growth scans for those at high risk of growth restriction - some women will be at increased risk of developing fetal growth restriction because of risk factors in the current pregnancy, past medical history or past obstetric history. All women should be assessed at booking for risk factors to identify those who need increased surveillance. Women who fall into these categories will need referral to a Consultant. The Consultant-led team will arrange for serial scans. Women will not require fundal height measurements while such a serial scanning protocol is being followed.
Growth scan requests related to obstetric history include:
Previous birth weight(s) <10th customised centile
Previous unexplained stillbirth
Growth scan requests related to maternal medical history include:
Pre-existing Diabetes
Chronic maternal disease e.g. renal impairment, vascular disease
Uterine fibroids greater than 6cm diameter
BMI >
Growth scan requests related to current pregnancy include:
Concerns related to growth measurements, as listed above
PAPPA-A (<0.4 MoM) and/or a low hCG (<0.5 MoM)
Impaired uteroplacental blood flow on uterine artery Doppler
Clinical suspicion of oligohydramnios or polyhydramnios
Known or suspected fetal anomaly
Fetal Echogenic bowel
Preeclampsia
Unexplained APH
Late booker (more than 20 weeks gestation)
Substance misuse
Multiple pregnancies
(refer to multiple pregnancy and birth guidelines)
Low placenta
(Refer to guideline entitled ‘Ultrasound management of low lying placenta, vasa praevia and placenta accreta identified at the anatomy scan.' 09015.)
If the placenta is covering or overlapping the os at 20 weeks, a growth scan is required at 32 weeks;
At 32 weeks, if placenta is < 25mm from the internal os, the scan should be repeated at 36 weeks.
Increased BMI
(Refer to the guideline entitled ‘Management of a pregnant patient with raised body mass Index.' 05092)
A growth scan is indicated at 36 weeks if the midwife or clinician is unable to confirm fetal well being and presentation at 36 weeks;
Where the pregnant woman has a BMI of 40 or more or trunkal obesity, serial growth scans are indicated at 34 and  weeks.
Diabetes in pregnancy
(Refer to guideline entitled ‘Management of diabetes in pregnancy. 04266)
For patients with pre-existing diabetes and gestational diabetes requiring medication, serial growth scans are indicated at 28, 32 and  weeks gestation.
For patients with gestational diabetes not requiring medication, there is no schedule of scans in place. These patients may require growth scans. This is at the discretion of the consultant.
Pre-eclampsia and mild hypertension
(Refer to the guideline entitled ‘Management of pre-eclampsia and hypertension on Day assessment Unit.' 1106)
A growth scan is indicated for a patient with recent onset of hypertension or pre-eclampsia is suspected. This growth scan is to be performed with an Umbilical artery Doppler

A growth scan and UA Dopplers are recommended in women with chronic hypertension. Carry out ultrasound fetal growth and amniotic fluid volume assessment and umbilical artery Doppler velocimetry between  and  weeks and between  and 34 weeks. If results are normal, do not repeat at more than 34 weeks, unless otherwise clinically indicated
Reduced fetal movements
(Refer to guideline entitled ‘Reduced fetal movements.' Register number 06034)
CTG criteria not met either by CTG or Oxford Sonicare CTG
Suspected SGA/ IUGR baby
Patient continues to perceive reduced fetal movements

Any other risk factor identified i.e. previous stillbirth, h/o fetal growth restriction, maternal hypertension, diabetes, extremes of maternal age, pimiparity, smoking, obesity, racial/ethnical factors and issues with access to care
An ultrasound scan is required within 24 hours or at the earliest working day.
Multiple Pregnancies
(Refer to Guideline entitled ‘Antenatal and intrapartum management of woman with a multiple pregnancy.'04254)

Dichorionic twins require growth scans at 24, 28, 32 and  weeks, if the pregnancy remains uncomplicated. This information should be given to the receptionists following the 20 week anomaly scan to ensure that there is no delay in the appointments. A double slot is required for each growth scan appointment.

Monochorionic twins which are uncomplicated should be scanned at 16, 18, 20, 22 and  weeks gestation for growth and to exclude feto-fetal transfusion syndrome (FFTS). These scans should be performed by either Mrs Thakur or referred to a tertiary centre to be scanned by a fetal medicine specialist.

In the absence of signs of FFTS scans should be repeated fortnightly until 24 weeks, growth scans at 28, 32 and  weeks, to be performed by the Sonographers in the routine antenatal ultrasound department.

Obstetric Cholestasis Liver ultrasound is indicated so this should be booked for all ladies with confirmed obstetric cholestasis but growth scans with no other clinical indications should be declined please. This is because the current evidence suggests that the risk of stillbirth in ladies with obstetric cholestasis is no higher than the general population.
Prolonged rupture of membranes (Refer to guidelines entitled
management of pre-term and pre-labour Rupture of membranes reg. no.08048)
Fortnightly growth and liquor ultrasound scans to be performed
Examination Preparation
No preparation is required for this scan.

One accompanying adult will be invited into the scan room during the anatomical checks. Children will not be admitted into the scan room until all of the checks have been completed. Any other people accompanying the patient, including children will be allowed to view the scan once the Sonographer is happy the scan is complete.
Consent
It is the responsibility of the Sonographer to ensure that the patient understands the scope of the ultrasound examination prior to giving her consent.
Verbal consent must be obtained for all examinations. Additional verbal consent should be obtained where a student Sonographer undertakes part or all of the ultrasound examination under supervision.
All patients must give informed consent prior to having a trans-vaginal scan
(Refer to Appendix B)
Timing of the Scan

There are multiple reasons, why patients require a growth scan or a series of growth scans. Please refer to the individual guidelines for clinical indications and timing of scans found on the intranet.
14 days is the minimum interval between growth scans to minimise false positive rates.
Performing the Scan
The examination should include:
Demonstration of the fetal heartbeat to the mother Where there is an absence of a fetal heartbeat, a second opinion should be obtained where possible
Assessment of fetal lie and movements
Assessment of placental site

Measurements of the femur length and abdominal circumference and where possible, the head circumference. (For correct sections, refer to diagrams in ‘Fetal anomaly scan 18+0 to 20+6'; guideline no. 10095)
Assessment of the stomach, kidneys, bladder and diaphragm
Interpretation of amniotic fluid volume should be based on single deepest vertical pocket
Umbilical Artery Doppler should be performed at all growth scans. The only exception is an ultrasound scan for placental site (only)
Where liquor is decreased and or the AC measurement falls below theth percentile, UA Doppler should only be performed from  weeks gestation onwards
Images to be Recorded
A series of static images should be recorded on the Radiology patient archive system (Insignia). This should include:
Where possible, A mid-line section demonstrating a sagittal view of the uterus demonstrating presentation and placental site.
Measurement sections of the abdominal circumference and femur length and where possible the head circumference.
A section demonstrating the stomach below the diaphragm (where possible).
Demonstrate the liquor volume.
UA Doppler, if performed.
Documentation
There should also be a permanent electronic record of all the imaging studies. The report should include:
Gestational age, EDD and number of fetuses
The presence or absence of the fetal heartbeat
Whether fetal movements were seen
Presentation
Comment on the presence of the stomach, kidneys and bladder.
The placental site
The liquor volume
Fetal measurements of the head circumference, abdominal circumference and femur length
Comment on any abnormalities found
Make a comment as to reasons why structures could not be visualised or measured.
Comment on if any measurements have fallen outside normal parameters, where the patient is being referred to
Comment on the end diastolic flow: positive, absent or reversed
Comment on suboptimal views due to increased patient BMI
Estimation of fetal weight should be recorded. With a comment of accuracy +/- 20%
The following comment should be typed in the comments section:
Fetal heart pulsations seen

Although fetal structures within our guidelines have been identified, ultrasound alone cannot exclude all chromosomal or genetic abnormalities. For patients who are above average weight the image quality is reduced due to increased body tissue depth
The coded text is USOBST
Pathway of Care following the Scan
The sonographer should check that the patient has an appointment with either a midwife or a consultant to review the results of the scan.

If the findings of the scan reveal that the measurements are below the th percentile, demonstrate reduced growth velocity or the liquor is reduced, Umbilical artery Doppler should be performed and the patient then referred to the antenatal clinic or DAU for further care.
If the findings of the scan reveal measurements above the th percentile or liquor is increased, the patient should be referred to the antenatal clinic or DAU.
If the results of the scan are essentially unchanged since the previous and a consultant appointment is in place, there is no need to refer to ANC or DAU.
Referral following a growth scan based on measurements plotted on GROW charts:
These referrals will be made by the sonographer once the growth scan has been completed and the EFW plotted on the customised growth chart with a circle. (GROW programme only)

If the EFW plots between the 10th and 90th centile and is following the centile Curve; and the liquor volume is normal the woman will be asked to attend her next antenatal appointment as planned (this should already have been confirmed with the woman by the referring carer).
If the EFW does not plot within the 10th and 90th centile or is not following a centile curve, or there are concerns regarding the liquor volume, then the following referrals should be made:
EFW above 90th centile (or significantly increased growth velocity)
For Obstetric SHO to review in Day Assessment Unit or Antenatal Clinic and repeat scan in 2 weeks
EFW below 10th centile, or reduced growth velocity, normal liquor volume, normal umbilical artery Doppler
For Obstetric SHO to review in Day Assessment Unit or Antenatal Clinic following a discussion with the Obstetric Registrar and repeat scan in 2 weeks
EFW below 10th centile or reduced growth velocity with oligohydramnios and/or abnormal umbilical artery Doppler.
For immediate obstetric review in the Day Assessment.
Communication - Patients
Following the scan, patients should be given a verbal and written report of the results of the examination.
Staff and Training

The procedures should be carried out by suitably qualified sonographers possessing the Diploma in Medical Ultrasound (DMU), a Postgraduate Diploma in Medical Ultrasound (PG Dip) or equivalent. Ultrasound students may carry out ultrasound scans under the supervision of a qualified sonographer.
Infection Prevention

All staff should follow the Trust's guideline on infection prevention whilst performing the scan, paying particular attention to the specific ultrasound protocols relating to the cleaning of ultrasound equipment which can be found in Appendix A and is also posted in ultrasound rooms and on the S drive.
Audit and Monitoring
Compliance with the guideline is monitored as part of an ongoing audit of imaging, completed by the ultrasound department.
Feedback to all staff is given on a regular basis and presented at staff meetings.
Poor compliance may lead to an unnecessary change in the patient's clinical pathway. In this instance, further training will be provided for staff if needed.
Equality and Diversity
Mid Essex Hospital Services NHS Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
Communication
Approved guidelines are published monthly in the Trust's Staff Focus that is sent via email to all staff.
Approved guidelines will be disseminated to appropriate staff via email.
The latest revised guidelines can be accessed via the intranet and clinical guideline folders in each ultrasound room.
Risk events / Error Reporting

All untoward events involving patient safety are reported to the risk management department and head of ultrasound by way of an electronic risk event form (Datixweb). This should be completed by the staff member(s) involved.
All errors are reported to the Radiology Clinical Director for discussion at a monthly radiology meeting.
References
The RCOG Green-top Guideline No.55 Late Intrauterine Fetal Death and Stillbirth Routine care for the healthy pregnant woman. NICE clinical guideline
The RCOG Green-top Guideline no. 31 Small-for-Gestational-Age Fetus, Investigation and Management
https://www.rcog.org.uk/globalassets/documents/guidelines/gtg_43.pdf
Nice guideline (CG107) Hypertension in pregnancy: diagnosis and management.
The RCOG Green-top Guideline no. 51 Management of Monochorionic twin pregnancy.
Appendix A
Ultrasound Department Mid Essex Hospital NHS Trust
Infection control procedure for the decontamination of Ultrasound Transducers. For intra-cavity and non-intra-cavity procedures.
Prior to vaginal ultrasound examinations
Ensure the patient is comfortable and relaxed.
Explain the procedure to the patient.
Obtain verbal/written consent from the patient for this procedure.
Confirmation of consent should be documented in the written report or in the patient's notes.
A Chaperone must be present throughout the scan, as per Trust chaperone policy.
If possible lock the door to maintain privacy.
Screen the patient to protect privacy while undressing – using the ceiling mounted curtain or mobile screen.
No one should enter the room, whilst the examination is undertaken.
Equipment
The equipment must be thoroughly cleaned prior to use and decontaminated after use and this should be documented in the written report or patient's notes.
The operators' hands must be washed and/or decontaminated with alcohol gel hand rub both before and after the scan.
Procedure – intra-cavity ultrasound
Examination gloves must be worn when carrying out the scan.
Apply a small amount of gel in the teat of the cover.
Cover the inter-cavity transducer with an ultrasound probe cover (all covers are single use only). Document whether latex or non-latex probe cover is used in the written report or patient's notes.
Use a non-spermicidal probe cover for infertility patients.
Use a latex free probe cover for patients with a latex allergy.
A single use sachet of lubricating gel is to be applied to the end of the inter-cavity transducer.
Undertake the procedure.
Procedure – Non intra-cavity ultrasound
Apply a small amount of gel to the surface of the transducer.
Undertake procedure.
Decontamination of Equipment after each Procedure

table_items.text: Remove excess gel with a paper tissue
Remove excess gel with a paper tissue

Clean and decontaminate the intra-cavity transducer and cable with a detergent wipe* by: (i) (ii) Covering the surface and sides of the transducer with the detergent wipe Rotate and progress the wipe along the length of the cable. (iii) This step should be repeated with a fresh wipe until the transducer and cable are visibly clean.
Clean all surfaces of the transducer and cable with a detergent wipe*.

Next decontaminate the transducer using Tristel Duo by: (i) Depress the pump once to dispense Duo Foam onto the surface. (ii) Use a paper towel and spread evenly. (iii) Ensure all areas of the surface come into contact with foam. (iv) Leave to dry, allow 30 seconds before contact.
Dry the transducer with a paper tissue
The non-intracavity transducer is now ready for the next patient

data.text: *Detergent wipes = Sani-Cloth Multi Surface Detergent Wipes
Appendix B
Equality Impact Assessment (EIA)
Title of document being impact-assessed:

table_items.text: Equality or human rights concern. (see guidance notes below)
Does this item have any differential impact on the equality groups listed? Brief description of impact.
How is this impact being addressed?
Ultrasound scans to assess fetal growth are only possible for female patients as the uterus, and fetus are examined.

Ladies of certain races or ethnicities may choose not to have an internal scan which may be offered if the trans abdominal examination is difficult. Patients may want to have a partner, friend or relative present for the scan. Patients may not want to undress for their scan. Patients may refuse their scan with

Patients have the right to refuse an internal scan and this is documented on the report. Patients may have one companion during the scan at the scan. This must not affect the concentration of the Sonographer. If the couple bring a child to the examination, then the partner is required to look after the child and not be present during the scan until the examination is completed. Once completed, family members/children are allowed to see the baby once the examination has been completed. A privacy curtain is provided for patients to undress behind. Covers are provided for the patient once undressed to maintain patient dignity. Patients also have a right to refuse examination by Sonographers of either gender. Patients will be rebooked to another list in the first available appointment slot if a suitable Sonographer is not available at the time. Every effort should be made to facilitate the
a certain gender sonographer. Language may be difficult if the patient's English is limited.

patient's understanding of the examination. Family members or friends may be used to translate where available. Translators are available to the Trust and should be used where possible. The Sonographer should decide whether the patient is suitable for the examination if the patient is unable to understand what is involved. This would mean that the patient was not able to fully consent to the scan.
Patients may have differing levels of ability or understanding.

The use of a hoist is available for those with physical disabilities as well as other manual handling tools such as sliding sheets. The procedures are explained to the patient by the Sonographer. The patient has the right to refuse any part of the examination and this should be documented in the report. The Sonographer should decide whether the patient is suitable for the examination if the patient is unable to understand what is involved. This would mean that the patient was not able to fully consent to the scan.
Patients of some religious groups or beliefs may refuse intimate examinations or may request a certain gender of Sonographer.

Patients have the right to refuse any part of the examination and this should be documented on the report. Patients also have a right to refuse examination by Sonographers of either gender. Patients will be rebooked to another list in the first available appointment slot if a suitable Sonographer is not available at the time.
Patients of differing sexual orientations may refuse intimate examinations or may request a certain gender of Sonographer.

Patients have the right to refuse any part of the examination and this should be documented on the report. Patients also have a right to refuse examination by Sonographers of either gender. Patients will be rebooked to another list in the first available appointment slot if a suitable Sonographer is not available at the time.
Patients of any age may refuse intimate examinations or may request a certain gender of Sonographer.

Patients have the right to refuse any part of the examination and this should be documented on the report. Patients also have a right to refuse examination by Sonographers of either gender. Patients will be rebooked to another list in the first available appointment slot if a suitable Sonographer is not available at the time.
Transgender patients may refuse intimate examinations or may request a certain gender of
Patients have the right to refuse any part of the examination and this should be documented on the report. Patients also have

a right to refuse examination by Sonographers of either gender. Patients will be rebooked to another list in the first available appointment slot if a suitable Sonographer is not available at the time.
Assumptions may be made as to the level of understanding of written guidance. .

The procedures are explained verbally to the patient by the Sonographer. The patient has the right to refuse any part of the examination and this should be documented in the report. The Sonographer should decide whether the patient is suitable for the examination if the patient is unable to understand what is involved. This would mean that the patient was not able to fully consent to the scan.
Carers may want to be involved as much as possible in the examination, for example in the moving and handling of the patient.
Help from carers should be encouraged by the Sonographer if the carer wants to participate and the patient gives their consent.
